issues.description: The problem statement text (line 50) instructs students to implement addGuestStudents(String) — i.e., a method taking a String — while the UML diagram (line 73) and the solution implementation (solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Lecture.java lines 90-92) define addGuestStudents(int): void. This parameter-type mismatch between the prose and the UML/solution can confuse students about which signature to implement and may cause them to write the wrong method signature (String vs int), which will not match tests or the intended design.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement prose to match the UML and intended implementation: change the text to describe addGuestStudents(int) (an int parameter) instead of addGuestStudents(String). This makes the parameter type consistent with the UML and solution and avoids student confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement's textual task description (line 50) specifies addGuestStudents(String), while the UML (line 73), the UML-related TODOs in the template, and the solution implementation use addGuestStudents(int). This mismatch about the method parameter type (String vs int) can confuse students about the correct signature to implement and may lead them to implement the wrong method signature or do unnecessary type conversions.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the parameter type consistent across artifacts. Update the problem statement textual description (line 50) to match the UML and implementation: change addGuestStudents(String) to addGuestStudents(int). Ensure the template's TODO comment and any tests reference addGuestStudents(int) so students have a single clear signature to implement.
